commits.message: Fix documentation links (#50695)
Fixed URL (#50690)
shims/scm: move to same path as Homebrew/brew.

Remove (almost) everything (#50678)

* cmd/help: tell people to run brew update.

* Remove (almost) all removable files.
Remove formulae/aliases/travis.yml. (#50676)
README: note migrations.

Update/split documentation.

Point to the new repositories instead.

utils, gist-logs: improve/fix credential handling.

The API used (`Net::HTTP::Post`) does not handle basic authentication
credentials in the same way as `open` so fix both cases so they work.

Also, do some general usability tweaks to point out to people what could
be wrong with their tokens or credentials to help them debug.

Closes #50410.

Signed-off-by: Mike McQuaid <mike@mikemcquaid.com>

bump-formula-pr: add new command.

Add a new developer command (i.e. requires `HOMEBREW_DEVELOPER` set in
your environment) to bump the version of a formula and create a new pull
request with the new version.

Closes #49848.

commit_comments.body: You forgot to update the MD5 here, I'll make a merge request for a version with a few more fixes too.

Good point on the CLUCENE_HOME, thanks for noticing that. If you would like clucene left in then I'll add it back. I've just been removing dependencies on the various KDE support dependencies unless someone specifically requests them. 

As for D-Bus not being picked up, I'm a bit more confused about this one. Could you do a brew install -i, run cmake and find the contents of the various D-Bus related variables and paste them here? Let me know if you need any handholding for this.
Yeh, I'm getting an MD5 mismatch here too. My only guess is that Nokia have changed the file again (I've known them to do this before). Fixing.
I don't think it should be as the dependency is optional but, arguably, it's important enough that it should be required.
Ok cool. Is there an FAQ on the exact usage of the above?
What's the difference in how the two actually affect things at the moment?
Ok, thanks Adam, good to know.
Github sucks, I was replying

Heh, thanks. 

I prefer to link to remote (and upstream patches) when I can so it's a bit more obvious when they don't apply or are no longer needed or whatever.

Will sort libpng check later. Hopefully have some KDEPIMLibs coming soon :)
I won't add any more, this is actually a runtime dependency of any KDE apps (on any platform). Fighting with the buildsystem to actually get the apps in though.
It's not actually used by kdelibs but is by kdebase-runtime so I might add it in there (when I get that formula working and commit it). Good point!
I should probably add a caveat about this. Try "export `dbus-launch`" and run it from that shell. I might add the dbus version with launchd support at some stage.

auklet: If you make the necessary upstream patches so this compiles in 64-bit without patches on Homebrew then it'll come back. Otherwise, I doubt it.

Like :D
I don't think people are as likely to read the Formula Cookbook as the documentation the program spits out.
Also, the new XCode coming will include Git :)
Yeh, I'm sure but some people just use system dependencies if they are there (myself usually included).

commits.message:
update: fix hyphen counting (legacy tap renaming)

Fix regression introduced in b2c31074e786835b45d0d07ca156cd3fb1ce2a9f.
Backported from Homebrew/brew@500f9eada854c1939bf9a0caf94085214c9399b0.
Counting the number of hyphens in a string cannot be done in a single
expression, thus split this and introduce another local variable.

update: remove stray comma (legacy tap renaming)

Fix regression introduced in b2c31074e786835b45d0d07ca156cd3fb1ce2a9f.
Backported from Homebrew/brew@93e0f4f9465978460d411f27214e19ae3fc4d294.

Revert "test-bot: clean up on Jenkins before building PR"

This reverts commit 51e4e6490bda0d981afd1787a6392ab588b0601c. This did
not work as intended, as the `git` command is executed in the context of
the tap the current job operates on, never for Homebrew/homebrew itself.

test-bot: clean up on Jenkins before building PR

Wipe everything from the Homebrew prefix except for the `Library/Taps`
directory to avoid having to refetch `homebrew/core` every time.

open-scene-graph: work around an SDK 10.11 issue

This is not a true fix, as the actual problem is in the 10.11 SDK, that
is used in a non-standard way. That way, the compiler doesn't see the
headers as system headers and (rightfully) complains about them being
broken in C++11 mode.

See also <https://plus.google.com/+ThiagoMacieira/posts/2SmArLfeDZt>.

Since the failure is not OSG's fault, it seems more fair to re-enable
support for 10.10/10.11 and just swallow the error caused by the broken
SDK header (by turning it back into a warning in C++11 mode).

Fixes #46372.

Closes #50229.

Signed-off-by: Martin Afanasjew <martin@afanasjew.de>
README: clarify and improve human parseability (#50664)

CoreTap#install: fix clone target setting

When invoking `brew tap homebrew/core`, the input options will be like
`{ :clone_target => nil }`. This renders `Hash#merge` a dead operation.

It doesn't impact Homebrew itself, but could cause problem for
downstream projects Linuxbrew/Tigerbrew when they adopt core/formula
separation.

This commit is backported from
https://github.com/Homebrew/brew/commit/1b7e13df4f936dd318a23698b7b69bd2ca0e2487

nesc: assign minimum emacs version

On certain system(e.g. fe22f59), `brew update` will report
`Error: Specify a version for EmacsRequirement` before it could run
migration for brew 0.9.9.

This commit workaround this problem.

update: use --replace-all to set remote.origin.fetch

Otherwise, it will fail on users who have multiple entries on
remote.origin.fetch.

various: add remote migration hack

Depends on what local revision users start with, there will be
several places which can be used to trigger remote migrations.
 * `tap_migrations`: some old system will load `tap_migrations` during
   `brew update`
 * `formula_revision`: old system whose revision is after
    c010cc8a8cadfe2e29f541570b70e62b6d735fb9 but before
    ac5707c37470c25583d8fb712bf5dc04ab91db4b will load `formula_revision`
    during `brew update`. This will help to solve #42553 on these
    systems
 * `update-reporter`: system since we implement bash update script.

Closes #50653.

Signed-off-by: Xu Cheng <xucheng@me.com>

gl2ps: prevent linking against X11's libglut.dylib

To avoid "accidentally" linking against X11's libglut.dylib when X11
happens to be installed, manually set

  GLUT_glut_LIBRARY=/System/Library/Frameworks/GLUT.framework

This allows the bottle build server to have X11 installed, but not end
up forcing us to add an X11 requirement to the formula.

Closes #50601.

FormulaInstaller: rescue tap unavail for reqs too

Calling `compute_dependencies` will make sure both requirements and
dependencies are expanded, so that any referenced taps can be
auto-tapped. Prior to this commit only dependencies were expanded for
the sake of auto-tapping, so dependencies of requirements would cause
installation to fail whenever a tap unavailable exception was
encountered.

Closes #50271

review_comments.body: This might be tricky. Taking a look at the script, it looks like it exits 1 on printing version or help, so we can't distinguish failure from success without doing a real run against a real djvu file.

Yeah, that's probably best. Unless we wanted to patch the script to exit 0 on version and help (which would be the correct behaviour, but it's not really up to us to take maintenance responsibility). I'll send a quick e-mail to the author, anyway.
Author is pushing a new version addressing this. I'll note the necessary changes when it's up.

Now that the new version's up, this should be

`url 'http://0x2a.at/site/projects/djvu2pdf/djvu2pdf-0.9.2.tar.gz'`
New md5 is `'af93c29a857a014f86dffcff6c773ef1'`
Good! I see there's still no explicit exit on version, but `system "#{bin}/djvu2pdf -h"` should pass `brew test` in the new version.
This comment can be taken out now.

This will fail on a standard OS X machine because Mac OS X doesn't alias `glibtoolize` to `libtoolize` by default; it quits with a message telling you to create the link.

If you add a line above this which reads `inreplace "bootstrap", "libtoolize", "glibtoolize"` then it'll work. This replaces more than just the line we need, but there doesn't seem to be any negative effect from it.
mpeg4ip installs its manpages in the wrong location by default. If you add `"--mandir=#{man}"` to the list of configure args, it'll install correctly.
The configure script didn't recognize `--disable-debug` and `--disable-dependency-tracking`, so they should be removed.

The commit is: michelSt/homebrew@15a78a4365612b56a7a8d18d75a9715777e8f141

As you can read hear: http://lists.gnupg.org/pipermail/gnupg-announce/2007q2/000254.html gnupg 1 is not binary compatible with gnupg 2:

> GnuPG-2 has a different architecture than GnuPG-1 (e.g. 1.4.7) in that
> it splits up functionality into several modules.  However, both
> versions may be installed alongside without any conflict.  In fact,
> the gpg version from GnuPG-1 is able to make use of the gpg-agent as
> included in GnuPG-2 and allows for seamless passphrase caching.  The
> advantage of GnuPG-1 is its smaller size and the lack of dependency on
> other modules at run and build time.  We will keep maintaining GnuPG-1
> versions because they are very useful for small systems and for server
> based applications requiring only OpenPGP support.

@wilkinson: Read this: http://progit.org/book/ A really good book.

One suggestion, always edit stuff in a separate branch:
`git checkout -b #NAME_OF_BRANCH#` Using the `-b`option changes directly to branch after it's created.

Push new branch:
`git push origin #NAME_OF_BRANCH#`

List branches:
`git branch -a`

Checkout branch:
`git checkout #NAME_OF_BRANCH#`

To keep up to date in the master branch:
`git checkout master && git fetch upstream && git merge upstream/master` _(upstream is the name of the remote server)_

This is because you have a dirty tree.

Easy fix:

`cd $(brew --prefix)`

`git branch -a` _(to make sure you are in the master branch)_

`git stage`

`brew update`

`git stage apply stage{0}` _(if you like to preserve your own changes)_

As stated by the [formula cookbook](http://wiki.github.com/mxcl/homebrew/formula-cookbook) page in the wiki:

> The mxcl fork doesn’t dupe stuff that comes with OS X or stuff that is provided by RubyGems, CPAN or PyPi.

One of the rules that has been adopted for the main homebrew repository is not to package-manage things for which there is already a dedicated package manager.  The reasoning is that a python package manager, such as `pip` can do a much better job of providing accurate, up-to-date installations than `brew` can.

Of course the wonderful thing about homebrew is that you are totally free to disregard any of the rules, make your own brew that does whatever the heck it wants, and use github to share it with your friends if you like.

I doubt this brew would be re-accepted even if it was patched to actually build.  The reasoning behind removing it was sound:
-  TeXLive is a large, complex system.
-  Large, complex systems are a pain in the rear to compile and maintain when they inevitably break.
-  There is already a dedicated team that is shouldering the responsibility of dealing with that pain in the rear.

Given the above points, we decided to defer to MacTeX as it provides a high quality TeXLive installation and reduces the amount of bug fixing we need to do.

The CMake args should incorporate `std_cmake_parameters` which sets prefix, CFLAGS and warnings. A good strategy is to:

``` ruby
args = std_cmake_parameters.split
args.conact [
  # Formula-specific stuff
]
```
The ParMETIS stuff should be left out---add it back in when Zoltan updates to a version that is compatible.

Homebrew provides some baseline CMake arguments via the `std_cmake_parameters` method which returns:

```
"-DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX='#{prefix}' -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=None -Wno-dev"
```

Setting `BUILD_TYPE` to `None` is important as it tells CMake to use our `CFLAGS` rather than creating it's own. This section should be re-written similar to:

``` ruby
args = std_cmake_parameters.split
args.concat [
  "-DTPL_ENABLE_MPI:BOOL=ON",   
  "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_Fortran:BOOL=OFF", 
  "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_EXAMPLES:BOOL=OFF",
  "-DTrilinos_VERBOSE_CONFIGURE:BOOL=OFF",  
  "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_ALL_PACKAGES:BOOL=OFF",
  "-DTrilinos_ENABLE_Zoltan:BOOL=ON",   
  "-DZoltan_ENABLE_EXAMPLES:BOOL=OFF",
  "-DZoltan_ENABLE_TESTS:BOOL=OFF"
]
```

gocode is pretty sensitive to being on the most recent go; the go compiler and gocode should be matched up. I suggest using this tag:

compatible-with-go-release.r60 which matches up with brew go which is at r60.1

given how tightly coupled gocode is to the version of the go compiler, I suggest that the go dependency is returned; otherwise you are going to get a bunch of people complaining about gocode not working.
